      Research and Innovation to help prevent the spread

      We’re working on a number of projects to help prevent the spread of COVID-19, from providing crucial screening to developing new antibody testing and supplying protective equipment.

      Boosting Covid-19 Testing in Northern Ireland

      The NHS is facing one of the biggest health crises in history and key to saving lives is the ability to rapidly scale up testing capability.

      A team from Ulster University have been working tirelessly with our partners in the WHSCT (Western Health & Social Care Trust) to ramp up testing at Altnagelvin Hospital. To date, the partnership has seen significant results with testing capacity increasing from around 10 to over 100 tests per day in the first week alone.

      Through a consortium (that includes Ulster University, C-TRIC and Queen’s) Ulster University, using existing supply chain connections was able to secure vital testing equipment, reagents and robotics, allowing for enhanced testing at the Western Trust, without compromising supplies to other regional testing centres. The initiative has resulted in the completion of over 1000 COVID-19 viral tests at Altnagelvin since efforts began in early April, illustrating the power of cross-sector collaboration with academia.

      In an effort to scale up testing further, Professor Tony Bjourson and his team have identified a robotic DNA purification machine which could increase output to as much as 500 tests a day. To finance the initiative, Ulster University launched a campaign that successfully crowdfunded donations in excess of £112,000 needed to purchase the machine, which is set to be in operation as early as the second week in May.

      Designing Medical Devices and PPE Prototypes

      As the number of coronavirus cases continues to climb, so does the need for the effective and efficient production and distribution of personal protective equipment and supplies for frontline and healthcare workers.

      In response, Ulster University’s School of Engineering is working with our partners in the Southern Health & Social Care Trust to design and fabricate innovative prototypes. Projects include prototyping respirator and aspirator covers, utilising the latest in laser and 3D printing technologies to support visor production, and devising low-cost hand sanitiser alternatives derived from coconut oil.

      COVID-19 Modelling

      Predicting the possible course of COVID-19 is of the utmost importance, as the true destructive nature of the disease unfolds. It's impossible to ignore the sheer number of statistics reported daily.

      Nevertheless, there remains much uncertainty of how the world will look, any more than a week in advance. Up to now, most modelling has focused on national analysis with little providing region-specific information - particularly in Northern Ireland.

      Ulster University has been working tirelessly with our colleagues from the Southern HSC trust (SHSCT) based at Craigavon Area Hospital to develop models that will better predict patient admissions, ICU bed demand and expected mortality rate. Furthermore, as data on transmission rates, incubation times and peak infectiousness continues to emerge these models will become even more refined, allowing for more strategic health planning and resourcing, which will ultimately lead to more efficient and effective care for patients.

      This collaboration represents the extension of an existing relationship between Ulster and SHSCT, and will feed into a newly established COVID-19 modelling group, set up by the Department of Health NI.
